quoteFirst: The amphitheatre, to which the viceroy, the nomarch, and the foremost officers betook themselves
quoteLast: was built in the garden of the temple. It was a circular space surrounded by a palisade twice the height of a man.
title: The Pharaoh and the Priest: An Historical Novel of Ancient Egypt

title: The Leicestershires beyond Baghdad
author: Thompson, Edward John, 1886-1946

quoteFirst: They come on with great regularity
quoteTime: about four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , and when they pass over, leave a delightfully cool evening. Like the mountains near Rio, the whole of the Organ range consists of granite.

Principally through the northern provinces, and the gold and diamond districts, during the years 1836-1841

quoteLast: --at least the rain had taken off, and the sun was setting with some wintry pomp--when the current of my reflections was effectually changed by the arrival of two visitors in a gig. They were farmers of the neighbourhood, I suppose--big, burly fellows in greatcoats and top-boots, mightily flushed with liquor when they arrived, and, before they left, inimitably drunk.
title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 20
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis, 1850-1894; Quiller-Couch, Arthur, 1863-1944 [Contributor]

quoteFirst: But we were nearing the mountains, an hour or two more and we should reach water, probably, so, though it was painful to deny the poor beasts, we kept right on, until
quoteLast: --for it had taken us longer than we had anticipated--when all three of them suddenly lifted their heads, pricked their ears and wanted to run forward. They smelt water ahead of them.
title: The Trail of The Badger: A Story of the Colorado Border Thirty Years Ago
author: Hamp, Sidford F. (Sidford Frederick), 1855-1919; Emerson, Chase [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , I reached the Caid's house; a woman, for a wonder, opened the door. As the Caid was there, I looked anywhere but at her.
title:
Notes in North Africa
Being a Guide to the Sportsman and Tourist in Algeria and Tunisia

quoteFirst: The play, I thought, will be curious, and therefore I decided to remain; and, after I had thanked the king for his kindness to me, he shook hands with me, and we separated. Evidently I was in high favour. On the following morning messengers came from the king to place horses at my disposal, should I be inclined to ride; but the heat was too great.
quoteLast: he again did me the honour of sending a horse to bring me to the palace. I wore a white coat, vest, and trousers; a helmet made of cork,[15] after the fashion of the ancient Romans, and covered with white muslin, completed my singular toilet.
title:
Travels in the Central Parts of Indo-China (Siam), Cambodia, and Laos (Vol. 1 of 2)
During the Years 1858, 1859, and 1860
author: Mouhot, Henri, 1826-1861; Mouhot, Charles [Editor]

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon

title: The League of the Scarlet Pimpernel
author: Orczy, Emmuska Orczy, Baroness, 1865-1947

quoteFirst: “Why, as to the company, that was remarkable enough!” said I, quaffing off a tumbler of champagne, to assist my invention. “You know it was
quoteTime: about four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: of the 18th that Napoleon ordered Grouchy to advance with the first and second brigade of the Old Guard and two regiments of chasseurs, and attack the position occupied by Picton and the regiments under his command. Well, sir, on they came, masked by the smoke of a terrific discharge of artillery, stationed on a small eminence to our left, and which did tremendous execution among our poor fellows—on they came, Sir; and as the smoke cleared partially away we got a glimpse of them, and a more dangerous looking set I should not desire to see: grizzle-bearded, hard-featured, bronzed
title: The Confessions of Harry Lorrequer — Complete
author: Lever, Charles James, 1806-1872; Browne, Hablot Knight, 1815-1882 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: While we were so hard pressed, two Iowa regiments approached from the rear, but could not be brought up to the severe fire that was raging in our front, and General Grant, who visited us on that ground, will remember our situation about 3 p.m.; but
title: Memoirs of General William T. Sherman — Complete
author: Sherman, William T. (William Tecumseh), 1820-1891

quoteLast: they took coach, and drawing up the windows, passed through Newgate, which then was similar to Temple-bar, and on to the Shears’-alehouse, in Maypole-street, by Clare-market; where, in the evening, he sent for his mother, and treated her with some brandy. As she knew the danger he was in, she advised him to take care of himself, and keep out of the way; but Jack had been drinking pretty hard, and was grown too wise to take counsel, and too valiant to fear anything; and, therefore, leaving his mother, he strolled about in the neighbourhood, from alehouse to gin-shop, till near 12 o’clock, when he was apprehended
title: The Life and Surprising Exploits of Jack Sheppard
author: Anonymous

quoteFirst: The 22d December, our irons were all taken off our legs, except the carpenters and smiths, who were detained at Mokha to set up our pinnace, and some sick men who were unable to travel. I and thirty-four of my people were destined to go up to Zenan, the chief city of the kingdom,[328] where the pacha resided.
quoteLast: of the 22d we left Mokha, myself and Mr Femell being on horseback, and all the rest of my people upon asses. About ten at night, when ten or twelve miles from Mokha, Mr Pemberton slipped away.
title: A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels — Volume 08
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteTime: about four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: when Dave met with a new adventure. It had more influence on his future career than he dreamed of at the time.
title: Dave Dashaway the Young Aviator; Or, In the Clouds for Fame and Fortune
author: Rockwood, Roy

quoteFirst: _Baldwin_ the third Mate, and the Gunner; there being some high Hills not far from the Place where they landed, the Mate and Gunner resolved to walk to the Top of one of the highest of those Hills, in order to take a View of the Country beneath.
quoteLast: they returned again to the Ship, bringing Word, that there was a pleasant Valley on the other Side, about five Miles in Length, and near as far in Breadth, but that they could see no Houses or other Signs of Inhabitants, but that the Valley seemed to abound with Deer, and several other Creatures; they brought on Board three Antilopes, and two large Guiney Hens, which they shot, and saw great Numbers of both these Creatures about the Bushes on the Sides of those Hills; the Antilopes were small, but extreamly beautiful, their Bodies no bigger than that of a Hare, but their Legs much longer, their
title:
The History of the Pyrates. Vol. II.
Containing the lives of Captain Misson, Captain Bowen, Captain Kidd, Captain Tew, Captain Halsey, Captain White, Captain Condent, Captain Bellamy, Captain Fly, Captain Howard, Captain Lewis, Captain Cornelius, Captain Williams, Captain Burgess, Captain North, and their several crews
author: Defoe, Daniel, 1661?-1731

quoteFirst: We entered the Eternal City at
quoteTime: about four o’clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: , on the thirtieth of January, by the Porta del Popolo, and came immediately--it was a dark, muddy day, and there had been heavy rain--on the skirts of the Carnival. We did not, then, know that we were only looking at the fag-end of the masks, who were driving slowly round and round the Piazza, until they could find a promising opportunity for falling into the stream of carriages, and getting, in good time, into the thick of the festivity; and coming among them so abruptly, all travel-stained and weary, was not coming very well
title: Turrets, towers, and temples
author: Singleton, Esther, 1865-1930 [Editor]

quoteLast: Lige announced that they had arrived at their destination.  Yet not a sign of Jose and the pack train could they find.  He had not arrived.
title: The Pony Rider Boys in the Rockies; Or, The Secret of the Lost Claim
author: Patchin, Frank Gee, 1861-1925

quoteLast: and we were in a critical situation, but having ordered Merritt to bring Devin and Davies to Dinwiddie by the Boydton road, staff-officers were sent to hurry Custer to the same point, for with its several diverging roads the Court House was of vital importance, and I determined to stay there at all hazards.
title: Personal Memoirs of P. H. Sheridan, Volume 2, Part 5
author: Sheridan, Philip Henry, 1831-1888

quoteFirst: A storm trysail was dug out from the obscurity of a musty corner of the lazarette, spars were lashed up for a sea-anchor, bags of oakum were soaked with oil and the life-boats provisioned and watered. When there was nothing more to get ready some one looked at the barometer to find--this was
quoteLast: --that it had risen twelve points since noon and was still displaying optimistic tendencies.
